articles.author: Hyunsu Yim, Hyonhee Shin
articles.description: South Korea's police chief became the latest top official to be arrested, Yonhap news agency said on Wednesday, in a widening investigation into President Yoon Suk Yeol's failed martial law that has plunged the country into a constitutional crisis.
articles.title: South Korea police chief arrested as Yoon impeachment looms over failed martial law

articles.author: Julio-Cesar Chavez, Rich McKay
articles.description: Luigi Mangione, the suspect charged with murder in the shooting of a top UnitedHealth executive, briefly struggled with officers and angrily shouted while being escorted into a Pennsylvania courthouse on Tuesday, as a clearer picture of his motives began to emerge a day after his arrest ended a massive manhunt.
articles.title: UnitedHealth murder suspect has angry outburst as details of his life emerge

articles.author: Maayan Lubell
articles.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took the witness stand for the first time in his long-running corruption trial, saying he was being hounded for his hawkish security policies.
articles.title: Netanyahu assails media as he testifies for first time in his corruption trial

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: Former South Korean Defence Minister Kim Yong-hyun, who is accused of playing a lead role in the failed imposition of martial law on Dec. 3, has tried to commit suicide inside a detention centre, a justice ministry official told parliament.
articles.title: South Korea ex-defence minister accused of role in martial law tries to commit suicide, official says

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: A federal congressman was assassinated late on Monday in Mexico's Gulf Coast state of Veracruz, the latest killing in an outbreak of political violence in the country.
articles.title: Mexican congressman gunned down as political violence continues

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: At least 229 people detained in Nicaragua for political reasons have suffered various forms of torture and other "crimes against humanity" at the hands of the government over the past seven years, a human rights NGO said on Tuesday.
articles.title: Nicaragua tortured at least 229 political prisoners, rights group says

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: China's naval deployments in the East China Sea and South China Sea are elevated but consistent with other large exercises in the past, a U.S. military official said on Tuesday, speaking on condition of anonymity.
articles.title: Chinese naval deployments in line with other large drills, US official says

articles.author: Kirsty Needham
articles.description: Bougainville must be able to fund at least half of its budget if the Pacific archipelago's aspiration of political independence from Papua New Guinea is to be a success, PNG Prime Minister James Marape said on Wednesday.
articles.title: Pacific island Bougainville's independence path relies on economy, says PNG's Marape

articles.author: Maya Gebeily, Michelle Nichols
articles.description: The lightning overthrow of President Bashar al-Assad left Syrians, countries in the region and world powers nervous on Tuesday about what comes next as the rebel alliance took its first steps in a government transition.
articles.title: Syria's rebels work to form government, restore order after Assad ouster

articles.author: Erin Banco
articles.description: The Biden administration has urged the rebel group that led the ouster of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad not to assume automatic leadership of the country but instead run an inclusive process to form a transitional government, according to two U.S. officials and a congressional aide briefed on the first U.S. contacts with the group.
articles.title: In first contacts, US officials urge Syrian rebels to support inclusive government
